Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Tuning Degradation Properties of Metallic Implants through Polymeric Coatings and Surface Texture

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
There are approximately 1.5 million arthroscopic procedures (interference screws, suture anchors) per year in the United States. However, the current generation of biodegradable orthopedic implants have not fully met expectations. Compared to commonly available metallic or polymeric implants, magnesium alloys combine the advantages of both into one material. Magnesium screws, for instance, can be made self-tapping and smaller in size than polymer screws, minimizing injury to the surrounding bone upon implantation. Yet, they are also degradable, opening up the possibility of fully bioresorbable metals. That said, the major limitation of magnesium is that its rate of degradation is too rapid for most clinical applications. This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) research project will investigate how thin barrier coatings on magnesium can be used to extend degradation time frames, which will usher in the next generation of fully degradable implants with fixation properties similar to currently available metals without the need for subsequent surgeries. As part of the overall effort, a concurrent and integrated educational program also is designed to train students and prepare them for the unique challenges presented by implantable materials. A collaboration with ConMed Corporation will offer tight integration between PhD scholarship and industrial skills in order to more thoroughly prepare students for jobs after graduation. The research will be broadly distributed into both classroom instruction and to middle and high school students

In this research project, biodegradable polymer coatings will be investigated to control the bioabsorption of magnesium implants delineating the interrelationships between coating process variables, coating composition, mechanical properties and life-cycle performance. Results will be benchmarked against currently available bioresorbable materials. By varying the composition and molecular weight of the polymer coating as well as changing the crystallinity and the thickness of the coating through processing conditions, it is hypothesized that water availability can be controlled in order to customize bioabsorption profiles of the implant. Lines of research that will be addressed include the following 1: How is water availability at the magnesium surface controlled by a degradable polymer coating? 2: What are the events of early pre-osteoblasts attachment followed by their subsequent proliferation and maturation into bone forming cells on polymer-coated magnesium model implants? 3; How does roughness of the magnesium surface affect the biodegradation of magnesium/polymer materials? The answers to these questions will enable predictions of degradation behavior over time to guide the design of future devices.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this project was to measure the rate of magnesium degradation under simulated implant conditions by varying water availability through the use of biodegradable polymer coatings. By varying the composition and molecular weight of the polymer coating as well as changing the crystallinity and the thickness of the coating through processing conditions, it was hypothesized that water availability can be controlled in order to customize bioabsorption profiles of the implant.  

There are three significant outcomes of this project. We investigated isothermal crystallization on the thermal relaxation of thin films of poly(lactic-co-glycolic acid) coatings (50-200 nm), which has important implications in the processing of the coating. We determined that after spin-coating, the films can only relax in one dimension (normal to the confining surface), as the presence of the substrate prevents relaxation parallel to the substrate.  This was established by measuring the coefficient of linear thermal expansion (CTE) of the polymer coatings and comparing the values to the bulk values. The CTE of the polymer coatings were approximately 3 times the value of the bulk sample, indicating minimal lateral relaxation.  If the polymer coating simultaneously crystallizes, crystallization further frustrates thermal relaxation leading to lower than anticipated coating densities. which has not been reported in the literature before. We were able to establish that coatings that were crystallized under isothermal conditions experienced a density reduction consistent with bulk samples; however, as the coatings were cooled to room temperature after crystallization, crystallites in in the coating in combination with the confining substate effectively disrupted the amorphous regions from completely relaxing. In other words, upon crystallization, a clear reduction in thickness of the coatings was observed, which is attributed to the formation of crystallites that deplete mass from the amorphous phase. However, the amorphous regions cannot contract in all three dimensions upon cooling leading to excess free volume in the amorphous phase. We hypothesize that this effect has a critical effect of the degradation of the semi-crystalline coating, and hence bulk crystallization rates underestimate the degradation of the thin coatings. We more over were able to map out the effect of heating versus cooling on the relaxation properties of the coatings.

 

In the second significant outcome, we showed that cross-link density and topology of cross-links in poly(lactic acid) affects both the crystallization rate of poly(lactic acid) coatings and the degree to which the coating can crystallize and degrade. Cross-links interfere with chain packing and reduce the efficiency of chain folding and crystallization. Further, chain connectivity induced network strain and resulted in lower melt temperatures. We tested models confirming that while cross-link topology has minimal influence on swelling of the coatings, cross-link topology a significant  influence on crystallization.

In the final aspect of the project, pillar-shaped microstructure patterns were fabricated on polished high purity magnesium surfaces by ablation with a picosecond laser. Micropatterned samples were further processed by stearic acid modification (SAM). Micropatterned surfaces with SAM had hydrophobic properties with water droplet contact angles greater than 130 , while the micropatterned surfaces without SAM remained hydrophilic. Corrosion rates on both hydrophobic and hydrophilic laser machined surfaces were reduced ~90% relative to polished surfaces. Surprisingly, corrosion rates were comparable for both hydrophobic and hydrophilic surfaces. Indirect evidence of local alkalization near microstructures was found and was hypothesized to stabilize the Mg(OH)2 layer, thereby inhibiting corrosion on hydrophilic surfaces. These results suggest additional processing to render the magnesium hydrophobic is not necessary since it does not significantly enhance the corrosion resistance beyond what is conferred by micropatterned textures. 

This project produced 3 PhD students.

 


Last Modified: 01/10/2021
Modified by: Ryan Toomey
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The overarching goal of this project was to measure the rate of magnesium degradation under simulated implant conditions by varying water availability through the use of biodegradable polymer coatings. By varying the composition and molecular weight of the polymer coating as well as changing the crystallinity and the thickness of the coating through processing conditions, it was hypothesized that water availability can be controlled in order to customize bioabsorption profiles of the implant. There are three significant outcomes of this project. This was established by measuring the coefficient of linear thermal expansion (CTE) of the polymer coatings and comparing the values to the bulk values. The CTE of the polymer coatings were approximately 3 times the value of the bulk sample, indicating minimal lateral relaxation. We were able to establish that coatings that were crystallized under isothermal conditions experienced a density reduction consistent with bulk samples; however, as the coatings were cooled to room temperature after crystallization, crystallites in in the coating in combination with the confining substate effectively disrupted the amorphous regions from completely relaxing. In the final aspect of the project, pillar-shaped microstructure patterns were fabricated on polished high purity magnesium surfaces by ablation with a picosecond laser.
